thread.title: 13.2MW Solar Plant Built Using 3D Measurement

title: 13.2MW Solar Plant Built Using 3D Measurement
text:
13.2MW Solar Plant Built Using 3D Measurement 13.2MW Solar Plant Built Using 3D Measurement Work load alleviated by accurate measurement of undulations 2015/09/16 17:30 Shinichi Kato, Nikkei BP CleanTech Institute 
The "Nagasaki Tadewara Mega Solar Power Plant" is a mega- (large-scale) solar power plant with an output of about 13.2MW that was constructed in the mountains in Tadewaramachi, Nagasaki City (Fig. 1). It was located on a site that had previously been planned for a golf course, and was completed in April 2015. Fig. 1: "Nagasaki Tadewara Mega Solar Power Plant" situated on a site that had originally been planned as a golf course. A 13.2MW-output mega-solar power plant was constructed in the mountains in Tadewaramachi, Nagasaki City. (source: Nikkei BP) 
The power producer is "Nagasaki Tadewara Solar JV," a special purpose company (SPC) financed 50% by Mitsubishi Corp's wholly owned subsidiary Diamond Solar Japan KK (Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo), 40% by Toda Corp and 10% by Mitsubishi UFJ Lease & Finance Co Ltd. 
Regarding the former golf course development of about 112ha, roughly 28ha was used for the mega-solar power plant (Fig. 2). Part of the land had already been reclaimed. Fig. 2: About 28ha out of the 112ha former golf course development was used. It took about one year to acquire permission and approval. (source: Toda)
